comments.content: C is incorrect because lowering the local pref of neighbor 10.10.10.3 on "R2" - sorry about that.

discussion.content:
D would be correct if it's on R2, not R1.

A & B are incorrect because local pref is the 2nd highest priority in route selection so meddling with metric will do nothing.

C is incorrect because lowering the local pref of neighbor 10.10.10.3 on R3 will also do nothing as it's already lower than 10.10.10.5.
It makes sense to make the change from D on R2, not R1

comments.content: After looking more this actually seems correct, R2 isnt even advertising a path from R5 to R1 because its ibgp -> ibgp, so unless R2 thinks its path is the best, it will never advertise one to R1
I disagree, setting the local pref to 50 on R1 towards R5 will make the routes from it appear less preferable than the default local pref of 100 towards R2, making R2 the preferred path out

choices.C: Set the local-preference to the default value with BGP neighbor 10.10.10.3 on R2 for receiving routes.
choices.A: Add metric 5 with BGP neighbor 10.10.10.6 on R5 for receiving routes.
choices.B: Change the metric attribute to 20 with neighbor 10.10.10.5 on R1.
choices.D: Change the local-preference attribute to 50 with neighbor 10.10.10.5 on R1.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct, without CEF, MPLS forwarding won't work.
B is correct, without CEF, MPLS forwarding won't work.

Selected Answer: B
Nothing else makes sense

Selected Answer: D
Why we should configure CEF on all routers in the MPLS network?? MPLS is already running and we want to add only few new PEs routers. 
What we need is to be open TCP/UDP port 464, which is needed for LDP discovery/ session build

comments.content: If I'm not wrong the LDP port is the 646 and not the 464 listed in answer D.

choices.C: Configure MVRF on all routers in the MPLS network.
choices.B: Configure Cisco Express Forwarding on all routers in the MPLS network.

discussion.content:
A B D are incorrect, and C is most likely trying hard not to say "configure IGMPv3".

In any case, C is the best answer.

This is tricky Q as PIM-SSM best supports solution "one-to-many" and video conference is "many-to-many" solution. Best way is to reconfigure it to BIDIR-PIM, but we do not have this option here. So if this Q is related to IGMPv3 as "serbam_17" mentioned, then Yes. Should be option "C". But who knows :-)
the answer probably wants to say to configure IGMPv3...

questions.question_text: A network engineer recently deployed a wireless network for users at a new office to join video conferences wirelessly. The existing network consists of routers that are configured for EIGRP and BGP, which are located at several data centers in different physical locations. The engineer configured PIM-SSM within a single domain from a single source. However, during the testing phase, the video conference failed to work for any of the users. The IPs are reachable and firewalls in the network are configured correctly to allow the traffic. Which action resolves the issue?

choices.C: Configure the devices to send join messages toward a multicast SPT.
choices.A: Configure PIM sparse mode to replace PIM-SSM.
choices.B: Configure PIM dense mode to replace PIM-SSM.
choices.D: Configure PIM dense mode with multidomain multicast.

choices.B: Configure BFD between each adjacent router.
choices.A: Configure IS-IS routing before implementing BFD.
choices.C: Configure BFD on any one of the routers.

questions.question_text: An engineer configured OSPF on all routers in the data center in the same exchange as other routers. Layer 2 connectivity was established. Now, the engineer plans to implement BFD to detect failures in the forwarding path. Which action must the engineer take?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
CEF is not mandatory for BFD to work

Selected Answer: D
I've always read that cef was required for bfd.. I don't see a reason not to pick D

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
